Historically Falcon rookies spend the majority of their first two seasons sidelined with injuries due to a weak conditioning program in training camp. Several never lived up to their hype because of permanent damage sustained in those wounds. Unless there has been a major revamping of the training regime, you can expect most of the highly touted rookies to wash out in a season or two.

We need to make sure we get RB Nick Chubb from the Georgia Bulldogs next year in the draft no matter how soon we have to draft him or go up and get him. He would help Matt Ryan tremendously and can carry this team on his back just as he carries the Georgia Bulldogs on his back. He can keep our defense off the field and fresh. The best defense is a great offense. We could score, run the clock down, and have so many weapons with Chubbs added to the team. I think with Chubbs along with our new additions this year and a few free agent additions we could go head to head with almost any team and possibly every team with Chubbs at RB to help our QB that is hard to bring down and draws 8 man boxes, which opens the passing lanes while preventing a fully committed pass rush bc Chubbs demands that elite respect to where you can't just ignore the run game. Our other RB's would compliment him well too. RB Nick Chubbs would be the one addition over everybody else that would help this team. You got to score points now! If Gurley stays healthy who runs just like Chubbs and who Chubbs took over for when Gurley got hurt, Gurley will run the Rams into the playoffs each year on his back. Chubbs is younger and more durable, and got better while doing just as good of job at RB for Georgia last year. In my opinion Chubbs will be the better RB and the best in the league, and Gurley will be a close behind him if he stays healthy. Plus they both can pass catch. An elite RB helps the team in all areas and on both sides of the ball. It isn't often these type of backs come along and especially in back to back years. We have to get Chubbs next year, especially since we missed out on the other home grown RB that can carry a team to the playoffs on his back this past year. A RB that scores points, opens the offense up, slows and stops pass rushers, and keeps the defense fresh is more important and does more for the team than any pass rusher no matter how many sacks.

data.name: 2015 Training Camp: Position Battles to Watch

data.message:
Tevin Coleman slight edge over Devonta Freeman. Tevin speed will work great during the first 3 quarters of the game and bring Devonta in during the 4th quarter more to wear the opposing defense down.

Jalen Collins outside corner and Robert Alford at nickel. Robert is a great corner but his game will excel in the inside where he can take more risks and not worry about giving up  big plays or TD.

Even though I have Tevin starting,  or at least getting the bulk of the carries, it is Devonta's job to lose. The scheme is perfect for Tevin who can break one loose like Antone at any given second. Devonta has hands though and if we run two back sets, the play action and draw plays will be studly. That's up to Kyle, though.

Jalen and Alford are too close to call. Ideally, I would like Jalen for his size but Alford's experience, hunger, and ball skills in general are hard to overlook. He'd be a great safety but we need him at corner. To me, it's a win-win. Both are dawgs.

Jalen Collins and Devonta Freeman

I think Coleman will eventually take over at some point, but Freeman is experienced. He'll start, unless Coleman blows coaches away in preseason games. I'm not sure about the other battle..

data.name: Alum Finneran Takes Pride in White's Growth

data.message: The first few seasons, Roddy could not catch a cold. He developed into a great player with great work ethic. He is a true leader and has helped all of our young receivers grow. Roddy is one of the best Falcons of all time. We will see #84 hanging from the new dome soon.

The article doesn't mention it, but, it was also ex-Falcon, ex-Saint WR Joe Horn who had the very same impressions, and impacts, on the younger, under-performing Roddy, just as Brian Finneran did.  Joe Horn also deserves some credit in lighting a fire under Roddy to get him to open up his talent and leave an impact on the team. (no this article isn't about Matt Ryan.  It doesn't have to be.)  http://espn.go.com/blog/nfcsouth/post/_/id/13686/roddy-white-has-become-consistency-model

data.name: RB Coleman Viewed as 'Potential Boom Pick'

data.message:
Great addition to Team ground pounder I can see him and the other RB's bringing back that DirtyBird
Dance ! Rise Up!!!
Dude was the best player on the Indiana team. He faced 8-9 man boxes all the time and still put up video game numbers.
I would love to see Coleman and Freeman trade off on rushing downs. Loved it when the Falcons had Cain and Andrews in the backfield back in the early 80's
As long as Antone gets touches.. I think our backfield is so powerful with Coleman & Freeman

I am expecting about 800-900 yards and 7-8 TDs from Coleman in his rookie year. I think he will establish himself as the #1 running back after the mid point if the season. Coleman could/should make QB M Ryan and the Falcons offense more balanced and thus better overall. He was actually the player I was most  excited about regarding the team's draft selections. And there were more than a couple of potentially good selections.

This blows my mind. I was the only fan allowed to break the rules. Why? I was motivating the franchise for free. In 2006 on April the 12th QB Michael Vick gave me the nickname STATS. I went to the Atlanta Falcons training camp from 2006 to 2010, as a fan. HARDCORE FACTS. In 2006, Michael Vick was the first quarterback to rush for over a 1000 yards in a single season. They finished the season 8-8, winning 6 of the first eight games. In 2007, WR Roddy White, had 83 receptions for 1202 yards 14.5 yards a reception and 6 touchdowns. In 2008, Roddy White had his first Pro Bowl appearance. In 2009, the Atlanta Falcons had the very first back-to-back winning seasons. In 2009, the Atlanta Falcons wore throwback uniforms for the first time in seven seasons. In 2010 Roddy White was the number one wide receiver in the NFL. From 2008 to 2010, HC Mike Smith's Atlanta Falcons were W 33 and L 15. I did not go to training camp 2011 - 2014, as a fan. From 2011 - 2014, with WR Julio Jones, Mike Smith Atlanta Falcons W 33 and L 31. I MOTIVATED THE Atlanta Falcons, as a fan, FROM 2006 to 2010. I MOTIVATED RODDY WHITE. His stats have gone down consistently since 2011. I have a God given talent to motivate athletes. The last time that motivated the team, November 30th 2014 vs the Arizona Cardinals. Arizona was 9 wins and 2 losses, the best record in the NFL. The Atlanta Falcons, 4 wins and 7 losses. RB Steven Jackson had his first and only 100 yard rushing game, and it was the only win the Atlanta Falcons had in 2014, beating a team with a winning record. It was 17 to 0 at the end of the first quarter, Atlanta Falcons. So if you are excited about the Atlanta Falcons, just know the Atlanta Falcons Motivator has not been hired yet. I, Michael STATS Wallin, AM THE ATLANTA FALCONS MOTIVATOR. YouTube: Stats the Motivator

data.name: Falcons Looking to Evolve at Tight End

data.message: I'm sure anything will be an improvement over the 5 or so catches we got from the TE position last year lol.

Tamme and Moeaki is an upgrade over Toliolo I am interested in how this plays out.  Toliolo was a reach even in the fourth round by Dimitroff *sigh*. Coach Quinn has final say over the roster.  Tamme is a solid TE

Tamme will start, he's one of those tight ends that seems to always be open and rarely drops the ball just like Tony G used to be for the Falcons. They could split the TE position into two groups- Tamme and Moeaki when they want to pass and Toilolo and Pascoe when they want  to run from goaline or short yardage situations!
Tony was pretty slow, for everyone saying bring back Tony, he had great hands but we need a TE who can stretch the field and who can block.
